section.title: creating a samba user
section.para: We will create a user for our samba file server and make this user the owner of the directory and all of its files. This anonymous user gets a clear description, but does not get a login shell.
section.screen: [root@RHEL52 samba]# useradd -s /bin/false sambanobody [root@RHEL52 samba]# usermod -c "Anonymous Samba Access" sambanobody [root@RHEL52 samba]# passwd sambanobody Changing password for user sambanobody. New UNIX password: Retype new UNIX password: passwd: all authentication tokens updated successfully.

section.title: ownership of files
section.para: We can use this user as owner of files and directories, instead of using the root account. This approach is clear and more secure.
section.screen: [root@RHEL52 samba]# chown -R sambanobody:sambanobody /srv/samba/ [root@RHEL52 samba]# ls -al /srv/samba/writable/ total 12 drwxrwxrwx 2 sambanobody sambanobody 4096 Jan 21 06:11 . drwxr-xr-x 6 sambanobody sambanobody 4096 Jan 21 06:11 .. -rwxr--r-- 1 sambanobody sambanobody 6 Jan 21 06:16 hoi.txt

section.title: /usr/bin/smbpasswd
section.para: The sambanobody user account that we created in the previous examples is not yet used by samba. It just owns the files and directories that we created for our shares. The goal of this section is to force ownership of files created through the samba share to belong to our sambanobody user. Remember, our server is still accessible to everyone, nobody needs to know this user account or password. We just want a clean Linux server.
To accomplish this, we first have to tell Samba about this user. We can do this by adding the account to smbpasswdsmbpasswd(8).
section.screen: [root@RHEL52 samba]# smbpasswd -a sambanobody New SMB password: Retype new SMB password: Added user sambanobody.

section.title: /etc/samba/smbpasswd
section.para: To find out where Samba keeps this information (for now), use smbd -bsmbd(8). The PRIVATE_DIR variable will show you where the smbpasswd database is located.
section.screen: [root@RHEL52 samba]# smbd -b | grep PRIVATE PRIVATE_DIR: /etc/samba [root@RHEL52 samba]# ls -l smbpasswd -rw------- 1 root root 110 Jan 21 06:19 smbpasswd
section.para: You can use a simple cat to see the contents of the smbpasswd/etc/samba/smbpasswd database. The sambanobody user does have a password (it is secret).

section.title: forcing this user
section.para: Now that Samba knows about this user, we can adjust our writable share to force the ownership of files created through it. For this we use the force userforce user(samba) and force groupforce group(samba) options. Now we can be sure that all files in the Samba writable share are owned by the same sambanobody user.
Below is the renewed definition of our share in smb.conf.
section.screen: [pubwrite] path = /srv/samba/writable comment = files to write force user = sambanobody force group = sambanobody read only = no guest ok = yes
section.para: When you reconnect to the share and write a file, then this sambanobody user will own the newly created file (and nobody needs to know the password).
